description:
The Indian sprinter Dutee Chand says she's glad others will not face similar abuse to her after being cleared to compete following a landmark gender case at the Court of Arbitration for Sport. The teenager was set to make her debut at last year's Commonwealth Games before being told she'd failed a gender test. CAS have said that the hyperandrogenism rules used by the IAAF will be suspended, adding that athletics world governing body needs to provide evidence about the effects of the condition. Chand has told the BBC that now others won't have to go through what she did.

"I never thought I would lose, because I always knew I was not a fault. I'm very thankful for the judges that they have taken a closer look at my case and given the decision in my favour. I have got justice. I'm a normal girl. I always knew I was going to win. When I got to know the judgement, I can't tell you how I felt. I'm happy that no one else would have to hear all the abuse that I had to hear."
